pageContent.title: <Introtext style="font-family:Helvetica; font-size:14pt; font-weight:bold; color:#cc0033; margin:10px -5px 10px 5px; width:738px; padding:5px 0 5px 5px; background:#e8e8e8; border-bottom:1px solid #333; display:block;">Caught By Surprise</Introtext>
pageContent.instructions: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:11pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:bold; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">How do you respond?</welcomeText >

choice.choiceText: A. Question Dr. Gomez to find out more about the concerns of Pharmacy. Based on her answer, provide strategies for effectively responding to such concerns in the future.

B. Tell Dr. Gomez that you will plan to meet with Michelle Hinley in Pharmacy. It has been some time since your last meeting with her, which occurred during the formulary review process. At that time, she was resistant but ultimately agreed to allow access to Samsca for nephrology. You will work closely with Michelle, discussing the benefits and risks of prescribing Samsca for heart failure patients with hyponatremia, and providing pertinent information, such as clinical trial results. Once Michelle understands the benefits of Samsca for use with hyponatremia in heart failure, she may be more supportive of its use.

C. Tell Dr. Gomez that resistance from Pharmacy is not uncommon during the early stages of prescribing; however, it will become easier as Pharmacy becomes more familiar with Samsca. Go back and review the marketing information to provide Dr. Gomez a balanced view of the advantages and tradeoffs involved when prescribing Samsca.
D. Confirm with Dr. Gomez the cardiology department’s priorities and restate the value of working with you to tie back into the department’s goals and priorities.

pageContent.summary: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:12pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:normal; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">Your customer is in the "deciding to trial" phase of the prescribing cycle. Setting clear expectations about insurance coverage is the best way to handle Dr. Bennett’s concern at this stage and to close on this phase of the prescribing cycle. If you choose to offer a creative solution to resolve his concerns (Choice A), you are jumping ahead to the next phase of the prescribing cycle, without closing on this phase. You have already worked through fair balance and have helped Dr. Bennett evaluate all his options, so Choice C is not the ideal way to respond, either. Choice D is an okay choice, but you should have already planned out your targets for this customer on a value map, so this may or may not resolve the current concerns they have. Choice B is the best choice.</welcomeText>

pageContent.title: <Introtext style="font-family:Helvetica; font-size:14pt; font-weight:bold; color:#cc0033; margin:10px -5px 10px 5px; width:738px; padding:5px 0 5px 5px; background:#e8e8e8; border-bottom:1px solid #333; display:block;">Identifying Stakeholder needs</Introtext>
pageContent.instructions: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:11pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:bold; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">What question will you ask in the meeting with Dr. Cardonza to identify his concerns?</welcomeText >

choice.choiceText: A. “Given the cardiology department’s priorities, what do you see as the biggest challenge you face in balancing increased patient satisfaction with the ongoing pressure to reduce costs?”
B. “What goals are you most interested in achieving?”
C. “What else, besides cost and minimal hassles, is important to you when deciding to prescribe a new product?”

D. “I recognize that I need to work more closely with Pharmacy to educate them on appropriate candidates for Samsca. If we get Pharmacy on board, and you are able to effectively treat hyponatremia with Samsca, how do you see it impacting the cardiology department’s goals for patient treatment? We do not have any data on patient outcomes in hyponatremia. What I’d like to speak to you about is the availability of Samsca at your institution and its benefits. The benefits of Samsca include increasing serum sodium concentration in patients with dilutional hyponatremia, oral administration, and no requirement of administration in the ICU or CCU.”

pageContent.summary: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:12pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:normal; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">You should use the information about the priorities that you have learned from Dr. Gomez and Dr. Cardonza in previous conversations (Choice D), thereby keeping the conversation focused and in context. Choice A addresses their priorities and challenges, but the question doesn’t address the current concern. At this point in the prescribing cycle it is not appropriate or effective to ask the customer about their priorities (Choice B) or what else is important to Dr. Cardonza (Choice C). Since the concern is clearly around the cost of Samsca and the recent hassle experienced in prescribing the product, Choice D is the best choice.</welcomeText>

pageContent.title: <Introtext style="font-family:Helvetica; font-size:14pt; font-weight:bold; color:#cc0033; margin:10px -5px 10px 5px; width:738px; padding:5px 0 5px 5px; background:#e8e8e8; border-bottom:1px solid #333; display:block;">New Opportunity</Introtext>
pageContent.instructions: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:11pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:bold; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">How do you respond to Dr. Gomez’s request?</welcomeText >

choice.choiceText: A. Quickly get a payor map, Discharge Checklist, and ACCESS brochure in front of Dr. Cardonza. You have developed a level of trust with both Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez, and you have a good understanding of their priorities. You can move forward.

B. This is a new opportunity. Prior to providing more information, make sure to explore and identify any other needs and to confirm how this fits with the department priorities and desired patient goals you have already identified with Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez.

C. Find out what other types of patients with hyponatremia in heart failure that Dr. Cardonza might be interested in now that he and Dr. Gomez are more open to your product. Make sure that you get the cardiology department prescribing your product for as many patient types as possible.

D. Now that Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez appear to be in the “evaluating the trial” phase of the cycle, you need to get information to them on insurance coverage and patient cost so you can ensure they have their questions answered up front and lessen the likelihood that they will explore other alternatives.

pageContent.summary: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:12pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:normal; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">This is a new prescribing cycle, and it needs to be treated accordingly. Choice A assumes that the understanding you have of the cardiology department’s priorities fits with this new opportunity as well, an assumption that could cause problems later in the cycle. Choices C and D both move you forward too quickly without ensuring that you have met all the customer’s needs in this phase, possibly creating mistrust later in the prescribing cycle. It is best to treat this as a new prescribing cycle and quickly identify any additional needs the customer may have so you can move forward with this new opportunity confidently. Choice B is the best choice.</welcomeText>

pageContent.title: <Introtext style="font-family:Helvetica; font-size:14pt; font-weight:bold; color:#cc0033; margin:10px -5px 10px 5px; width:738px; padding:5px 0 5px 5px; background:#e8e8e8; border-bottom:1px solid #333; display:block;">Direction from your District Manager</Introtext>
pageContent.instructions:
However, Dr. Cardonza left the meeting prior to making a prescribing decision. It’s the end of the quarter. Your district manager is encouraging you to achieve the desired results.

What is the right action to take at this time?

choice.choiceText: A. Spend the time necessary to identify any concerns Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez may have about initiating Samsca in the hospital and continuing treatment on an outpatient basis. This is a necessary step to help ensure that the physicians know how to access Samsca.

B. It’s time to close the sale. Stop by the Maycomb cardiology department again and meet with Dr. Cardonza, reinforcing the benefits of initiating Samsca in the hospital for appropriate patients and, when appropriate, continuing that therapy after discharge.

C. It doesn’t have to take a long time to move through the prescribing cycle. Immediately provide Dr. Cardonza the information on product coverage and patient cost, and any other information he may need to move forward with prescribing.
D. Do more than just provide the product coverage and patient cost information. Remind Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez of the value Samsca may bring to their department by addressing their priorities.

pageContent.summary: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:12pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:normal; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">Making sure you have addressed concerns about the possible benefits and risks of continuing treatment in the outpatient setting increases the chances that the sale will be successful (Choice A). This doesn’t have to take a long time, and you might even expand prescribing more than what the customer originally intended. Moving forward with patient cost and insurance coverage too early without giving the customer the opportunity to express any concerns about risks (Choices B and C) may prove successful in the short term, but it could slow things down later. If the customer has to identify risks on their own without your guidance, you risk damaging your position as a trusted advisor. Choice D focuses too heavily on your past relationship with the customer and your product’s value, rather than on the customer’s needs. Choice A is the best choice.</welcomeText>

pageContent.title: <Introtext style="font-family:Helvetica; font-size:14pt; font-weight:bold; color:#cc0033; margin:10px -5px 10px 5px; width:738px; padding:5px 0 5px 5px; background:#e8e8e8; border-bottom:1px solid #333; display:block;">Creating Value</Introtext>
pageContent.instructions: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:11pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:bold; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">You have scheduled a meeting with Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez to evaluate their initial results and to make sure that no issues have arisen since they began prescribing. How do you help Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez to see the early value of their decision to prescribe Samsca? </welcomeText >

choice.choiceText: A. Plan for the meeting using your Value Map, and discuss with Dr. Gomez your ideas for evaluating their results.
B. Learn fromDr. Gomez and Dr. Cardonza their process for evaluating both short-term and long-term results, and then schedule time to follow up.

C. There won’t be much information available yet, since the cardiologists just started prescribing Samsca, so use this meeting to talk through any issues that may have arisen. Set up another meeting with Dr. Gomez and Dr. Cardonza for six weeks out, when more information will be available, to ensure maximum impact.
D. Discuss how adding Samsca to their therapeutic regimen helped other customers achieve goals that the Maycomb cardiology department wants to achieve.

pageContent.summary: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:12pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:normal; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">Working with Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez to create a process for evaluating the impact of your product is a great way to show not only the value of Samsca but also the value you offer as an ongoing partner and advisor (Choice B). The Value Map that you created in your planning will be very useful here (Choice A), but it’s better to help them establish an ongoing process for evaluating the impact of prescribing Samsca, both now and in the future. Choice C does not fully utilize this time you have with Dr. Cardonza and Dr. Gomez to show the value you offer as a partner and advisor. Choice D would be appropriate earlier in the prescribing cycle, but this option is also inappropriate as we do not have any outcomes data for Samsca. Choice B is the best choice.</welcomeText>

pageContent.title: <Introtext style="font-family:Helvetica; font-size:14pt; font-weight:bold; color:#cc0033; margin:10px -5px 10px 5px; width:738px; padding:5px 0 5px 5px; background:#e8e8e8; border-bottom:1px solid #333; display:block;">Scheduling Conflict</Introtext>
pageContent.instructions:
You already have plans for a ride along with Dan, a new account manager for OAPI, for him to see your day in action. It has taken awhile to coordinate your schedules, and you know he is eager to get a better understanding of how you work.

What should you do?

choice.choiceText: A. Call Dan to see if it’s possible to reschedule the ride along session. You might not get another opportunity to meet with Dr. Chu.

B. Tell Dr. Gomez that you already have a commitment on Friday, and ask him to see if there is another day Dr. Chu can meet. The ride along with Dan was scheduled first, and you don’t want to risk that relationship.

pageContent.summary: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:12pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:normal; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">Although it’s always important to keep commitments, in this instance it’s worth making a phone call to Dan to see if anything has changed and if he’s willing to reschedule the ride along. You might even be able to work with your own schedule to make the ride along happen sooner, or come up with another creative solution. Choice A is the best choice. </welcomeText>

pageContent.title: <Introtext style="font-family:Helvetica; font-size:14pt; font-weight:bold; color:#cc0033; margin:10px -5px 10px 5px; width:738px; padding:5px 0 5px 5px; background:#e8e8e8; border-bottom:1px solid #333; display:block;">Understanding and Accelerating Customer Outcomes</Introtext>
pageContent.instructions: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:11pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:bold; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">How should you proceed during the meeting with Dr. Chu? </welcomeText >

choice.choiceText: A. Capitalize on your success. Review your existing Value Map that you developed while planning for Dr. Cardonza’s meeting and arrange a few marketing pieces for Dr. Chu.

B. Compile all marketing material, clinical trial results, and insurance coverage information for your product. Since Dr. Chu has previously been concerned about safety, you want to be sure you give him all the available information on Samsca.
C. Discuss overall patient priorities with Dr. Chu in order to start planning a new Value Map for him as a hospitalist.
D. Focus on the value you personally can bring to Dr. Chu.

pageContent.summary: <welcomeText style=" font-family:Helvetica; font-size:12pt; line-height:18pt; text-align:justify; font-weight:normal; color:#333; display:block; margin:0 10px 10px">After monitoring patients, your customer is in the “evaluating” phase of the prescribing cycle. Because Dr. Chu has already talked with Dr. Gomez, Choice A would not be the best use of your time with Dr. Chu. Although providing information to Dr. Chu is useful, it is not the best use of a first meeting, especially considering that he is already fairly familiar with Samsca. As a result, Choice B would not be appropriate or useful. Choice D is an okay choice because it involves focusing on the value you bring for Dr. Chu and the hospitalists, but it doesn’t allow you to involve Dr. Chu in the process as both a partner and an advisor. Choice C is the best choice. </welcomeText>
